para.p: In this document, we will derive the orthographic projection matrix created by this library. This matrix is for a right handed coordinate system and it follows OpenGL conventions for eye and clip space.

In the eye coordinate space, the eye or the camera is at the origin
[ 0 , 0 , 0 ]
and it looks down the negative z-axis

In the clip coordinate space, the clipping volume is a cube of length 2. Coordinates of all points inside the clipping volume are in the range
[
- 1
, 1 ]
.

The key difference between the eye and clip space is the orientation of z-axis. In clip space, the positive z-axis is into the screen, in the eye space it is out of the screen.
1 1 footnote 1 I suspect the reason for
+ z
in clip space pointing into the screen is for ease of depth buffer comparison–if an incoming fragment’s
z
value is less than the previous depth value, it is accepted as it is nearer. If it was the other way around, larger z values would be considered closer to the camera and it sounds unnatural.
The purpose of the orthographic matrix is to transform coordinates from the eye space to the clip space.
In the eye space, a point’s x-coordinate’s relationship to the clipping planes is
In the clip space, the same relationship is
The goal of the orthographic matrix is to convert to the second form and it happens by the following set of operations

equationgroup.p: Subtract L from all sides of the inequality

para.p: Similarly for y, we can derive the relationship

For z, things get a little different because of the fact that both near and far clipping planes are planes are along the negative z-axis in the eye space. Since both near and far are negative, it must be observed that z-coordinate in eye space obey the relationship
Applying the same principle as above, we can continue the derivation

equationgroup.p: Subtract F from all sides of the inequality

para.p:
Arranging these expressions in a matrix form such that
[ x , y , z ]
will transform to these expressions produces matrix

Applying this matrix to
[
x
⁢ e y e
,
y
⁢ e y e
,
z
⁢ e y e
, 1 ]

produces the clip space coordinates 2 2 footnote 2 Note that the
w
coordinate is
1
. Therefore, when this 4D coordinate is converted to 3D by dividing by
w
, the z-coordinate remains unchanged. This is why there is no perspective foreshortening in orthographic projection
